title: Dangling Modifiers
description: Spot the dangling and misplaced modifiers that can turn sentences into unintentional comedy!

questions.question: Which sentence has a dangling modifier?
options: While I was walking to the store, the rain began.
The rain began while I walked to the store.
Walking to the store, the rain began to fall.
I was walking to the store when it rained.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly fixes a dangling modifier?
options: Running quickly, she crossed the finish line.
Crossed was the finish line, running quickly.
The finish line, running quickly, was crossed.
Running quickly, the finish line was crossed.

questions.question: Which sentence contains a misplaced modifier?
options: She drove her kids to school almost every day.
She drove her kids to school on most days.
Nearly every day, she drove her kids to school.
She almost drove her kids to school every day.

questions.question: What is a dangling modifier?
options: A modifier with too many adjectives
A modifier that doesn't clearly refer to the word it modifies
A modifier at the end of a sentence
A modifier that uses a hyphen

questions.question: Which sentence has a dangling modifier? 'After reading the book, ___.'
options: Both B and C
I wrote a review.
my opinion changed.
the review was written.

questions.question: Fix the dangling modifier: 'Covered in mud, the washing machine cleaned the dog's blanket.'
options: The washing machine cleaned the dog's blanket, covered in mud.
The washing machine, covered in mud, cleaned the blanket.
Covered in mud, the dog's blanket was cleaned in the washing machine.
In mud covered, the blanket was washed.

questions.question: Which sentence has a misplaced modifier?
options: He served sandwiches to the guests on paper plates.
On paper plates, he served sandwiches to the guests.
He served the guests sandwiches on paper plates.
He served sandwiches on paper plates to the guests.

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: The essay was submitted hoping to win the prize.
Hoping to win the prize, the essay was submitted.
Hoping to win the prize, she submitted her essay.
Submitted was her essay, hoping to win.

questions.question: Identify the dangling modifier: 'At the age of five, my grandmother taught me to knit.'
options: There is no error.
'My grandmother' is misplaced.
'At the age of five' seems to modify 'grandmother' instead of 'me.'
'Taught' is in the wrong tense.

questions.question: Which correction fixes the misplaced modifier? 'She only ate vegetables on Mondays.'
options: Only she ate vegetables on Mondays.
She ate only vegetables on Mondays.
It depends on the intended meaning.
She ate vegetables only on Mondays.

questions.question: Which sentence has a dangling modifier?
options: While driving to work, a deer crossed the road.
I saw a deer cross the road while driving.
A deer crossed the road while I drove to work.
While I was driving to work, a deer crossed the road.

questions.question: Where is the modifier misplaced? 'I saw a man on the hill with a telescope.'
options: 'On the hill' could modify 'I' or 'man.'
'Saw' is in the wrong position.
There is no misplaced modifier.
'With a telescope' could modify 'I,' 'man,' or 'hill.'

questions.question: Fix: 'Smelling of fresh flowers, I walked through the garden.'
options: Smelling of fresh flowers, the garden was where I walked.
Through the garden of fresh flowers, I smelled walking.
I walked through the garden smelling of fresh flowers.
I walked through the garden, which smelled of fresh flowers.

questions.question: Which word placement causes a misplaced modifier? 'She nearly lost all her money.'
options: The sentence is correct as written.
'Nearly' should come after 'lost' â€” 'She lost nearly all her money.'
'All' is in the wrong position.
'She' should come after 'nearly.'

questions.question: Which sentence avoids a dangling modifier?
options: Born in 1920, the war shaped her childhood.
The war shaped her childhood, born in 1920.
In 1920 born, the war shaped her.
Born in 1920, she grew up during the war.
